marketNews.title: Other hot news to know
marketNews.content:
1. The Wall Street Journal reported that U.S. President Donald Trump told senior officials on Tuesday (June 17) that he approved a plan to strike Iran, although the plan remains on hold pending whether Iran will halt its nuclear program. When asked by reporters on Wednesday (June 18) whether he had decided to attack Iranian nuclear facilities, Trump said he had not made a final decision and again urged Iran to surrender unconditionally. On Wednesday (June 18), Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said the country would not surrender and warned that U.S. military intervention would bring irreversible consequences.
2. The U.S. Federal Reserve on Wednesday (June 18) decided to keep the policy rate at 4.25-4.50%, in line with consensus expectations, amid uncertainty caused by U.S. tariffs. The Fed still projects a 50 basis-point rate cut by the end of 2025, implying two 25-basis-point reductions. The projection is unchanged from the December 2024 and March 2025 forecasts, but the latest dot plot shows a split among Fed members.
3. Bloomberg reported that a group of Indonesian HPAL smelters could see margin compression due to a more than three-fold increase in sulfur prices over the past year, a key raw material for producing mixed-hydroxide precipitate (MHP). Analysts at SMM Information & Technology Co. said the sulfur price surge would raise the cost of producing one ton of MHP by about USD 2,500 compared with last year. The average cost to produce one ton of MHP is now around USD 11,000, and each ton requires 12 tons of sulfur.
4. An Indian palm-oil refiner cancelled orders for 65,000 tons of CPO for July-September 2025 shipments because of a sudden surge in the Malaysian reference price, according to four anonymous sources cited by Reuters. Nevertheless, Sunvin Group CEO Sandeep Bajoria expects Indian CPO imports to rise in the coming months, driven by low inventories after a period of weak imports. Indian CPO imports reached a six-month high in May 2025, supported by low stock levels and discounts relative to soybean and sunflower oil.
5. Danantara COO Dony Oskaria said on Wednesday (June 18) that the company now has authority to inject capital into state-owned enterprises, eliminating the need for further state-owned enterprise capital participation (PMN). In providing capital, Danantara will assess the business plans of the targeted SOEs, including industry forecasts.
6. The Ministry of Environment will impose administrative sanctions on PT Indonesia Morowali Industrial Park (IMIP) in Central Sulawesi because of environmental regulation violations in the industrial zone. Environment Minister Hanif Faisol Nurofiq said inspections found facilities not covered by the environmental impact analysis (AMDAL) and uncovered a land opening of roughly 179 hectares directly adjacent to IMIP. The IMIP industrial area spans about 2,000 hectares and currently hosts 28 operating companies with 14 under construction.

tickerNews.title: CDIA announces IPO with valuation Rp21-24 trillion
tickerNews.content:
Subsidiary of Chandra Asri Pacific (TPIA), Chandra Daya Investasi (CDIA), announced that it will carry out an IPO offering up to 12.5 billion new shares (10% of the company) at a price range of IDR 170-190 per share. This implies a target fund raise of approximately IDR 2.1-2.4 trillion, with a market capitalization of about IDR 21-24 trillion.

CDIA is a subsidiary of TPIA operating as a holding in infrastructure sectors such as energy, water, ports and storage, and logistics. Currently, the company together with its subsidiaries and associate entities holds assets as follows:
1. Steam gas power plants (PLTGU) with capacity of 120 MW and 200 MW through a joint venture with PT Krakatau Posco, where KCE holds 45%.
2. Water treatment plant Krenceng with capacity of 1,800 liters per second.
3. 72 tanks with capacity of 130,000 cubic meters.
4. 7 chemical and gas carriers with capacity of 5,000-8,600 DWT.

Shareholder structure after the IPO: TPIA 60%, Phoenix Power/EGCO Group Thailand 30%, public investors 10%.

Valuation after IPO: CDIA is expected to have a valuation of approximately 42.5-47.5 times 2024 earnings (P/E) and a price-to-book ratio of 1.7-1.8 times, based on 2024 financial statements.

Financial performance: In 2024, CDIA recorded revenue of USD 102.3 million and net profit of USD 30.6 million. This performance is higher than the revenue of USD 75.8 million and net profit of USD 0.18 million recorded for the period 8 February-31 December 2023.

Use of IPO proceeds:
1. 37% will be injected as capital into logistics business subsidiaries, namely PT Chandra Shipping International and PT Marina Indah Maritim, for ship purchases and operational financing.
2. 63% will be injected as capital into port and storage business subsidiaries, namely PT Chandra Cilegon Port, for building storage tanks, ethylene pipelines, and other supporting facilities.

tickerNews.title: BUMI plans to issue bonds up to IDR 350 billion to fund acquisition of Wolfram Limited
tickerNews.content: BUMI Resources plans to issue bonds up to IDR 350 billion. The proceeds will be used to partially finance the planned acquisition of Wolfram Limited, an Australian copper and gold mining company. The bonds have received an idA+ rating from Pefindo.

tickerNews.title: Grab's merger with GoTo faces Indonesian regulatory hurdles
tickerNews.content: Grab Holdings Ltd. (Nasdaq: GRAB) is encountering regulatory obstacles in its planned acquisition of GoTo Gojek Tokopedia. Three anonymous sources told Reuters that the merger requires more time for approval after the Indonesian government proposed several conditions. The government is reviewing how the merger could affect worker welfare and market competition in Indonesia.

tickerNews.title: Blue Bird approves dividend of IDR 120 per share for FY 2024
tickerNews.content: Blue Bird shareholders approved a dividend plan for fiscal year 2024 amounting to IDR 300.25 billion, or IDR 120 per share. This corresponds to a dividend payout ratio of approximately 51.3% (2023: 50.3%) and indicates a dividend yield of about 6.3% as of Thursday (June 19). The cum-date and payment date have not been announced.

tickerNews.title: Merck declares FY 2024 dividend of IDR 170 per share
tickerNews.content: Merck will distribute a dividend for fiscal year 2024 of approximately IDR 76.2 billion, or IDR 170 per share. This equals a dividend payout ratio of 50% (2023: 80%) and indicates a dividend yield of about 5% as of Thursday (June 19). The cum-date is on the regular market and negotiation on June 24, 2025, with payment scheduled for July 15, 2025.

tickerNews.title: PTMP targets revenue growth of 20-30% YoY in 2025
tickerNews.content: Mitra Pack (PTMP) CEO Ardi Kusuma said the company aims for sales growth of about +20-30% year-on-year in 2025, with net profit expected to increase by at least +15% YoY. The company will strengthen its position as a leading provider of innovative and environmentally friendly packaging solutions and will expand its distribution network to meet growing market demand.

tickerNews.title: Tempo Inti Media's subsidiary creates Pal8 Pictures for film production
tickerNews.content: Tempo Inti Media announced that its subsidiary, PT Dimensi Idea Kreatif, has established a company called Pal8 Pictures to operate in the film industry. Pal8 Pictures is founded together with PT Putri Bakti, with PT Dimensi Idea Kreatif holding a 60% stake. The new company will develop the creative industry sector by producing films inspired by Tempo's journalistic content and digital channels.

tickerNews.title: Wilmar Cahaya Indonesia clarifies no legal link to IDR 11.8 trillion guarantee
tickerNews.content: Wilmar Cahaya Indonesia stated in a clarification to the IDX that the company has no legal relationship or connection regarding the news of an IDR 11.8 trillion guarantee provided by the Wilmar Group to the Attorney General's Office, as the report did not mention the company by name.
